intro: Pinus arizonica subsp. cooperi, commonly known as the Arizona white pine, is a subspecies native to the southwestern United States. It is a medium-sized evergreen conifer with slender, blue-green needles and a conical shape. The tree produces cones that are typically 5–8 cm long, containing edible seeds that are a food source for various wildlife. It thrives in well-drained soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. The subspecies is distinguished by its shorter needles and more open crown compared to other Pinus arizonica varieties.
